Hybrid learning environment: Collaborative or competitive learning?
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • S.I. : VR in Education
  • Published: 14 July 2018

Hybrid learning environment: Collaborative or competitive learning?

  • Calixto Gutiérrez-Braojos  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-6901-25661,
  • Jesus Montejo-Gamez2,
  • Ana Marin-Jimenez3 &
  • Jesús Campaña4 

Virtual Reality volume 23, pages411–423(2019)Cite this article

  • 700 Accesses

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The aim of this study is to analyze the effect of different conditions of face-to-face learning on the participation and learning of students in the virtual community. In particular, we analyze the effect of collaboration vs intergroup competition learning on interdependence, regulation of socio-cognitive conflict, participation, and the quality of the contributions in a virtual learning platform. This study took place in an educational research course. The participants in the full investigation were 36 (94.44% females) undergraduates enrolled in the subject of educational research, which was part of a 4-year social education degree program. A Latin Squares design was applied to carry out the full investigation. The results show that conditions of collaboration without competition in face-to-face environments facilitate better quality of learning to a greater extent. In addition, there are no benefits of intergroup competition over individual competition learning. Thus, in this study, collaborative learning designs without any competition could be considered more consistent with the goal that underpins the main right to education: Each student is able to achieve what he has to achieve, taking advantage of the abilities of each and every agent in the learning community (teacher and students) to do so. These results are not consistent with previous studies. We suggest that characteristics of the sample could explain these differences between studies.

Introduction

The fast growth and improvement in online technologies in recent years has elicited the appearance and development of virtual learning (VL), which is usually organized through virtual communities. Virtual learning communities refer to cyberspaces in which individuals and groups of individuals accomplish their learning goals (Yang et al. 2007). Dillenbourg et al. (2002) describe the main features of VL environments. These authors also point out that virtual learning communities are not restricted to systems that include 3D or virtual reality technology; instead, they can include exclusively text-based interfaces. Use of VL environments in university degrees shows some advantages. First of all, Virtual Learning Technologies make it possible to implement hybrid modalities. Thus, they constitute a useful tool for distributing students’ workload between the classroom and home, according to European directives for higher education (European Commission 2015). These hybrid modalities can be understood as ‘the thoughtful integration of classroom face-to-face learning experiences with online learning experiences’ (Garrison and Kanuka 2004, p. 96). In this context, technology provides more opportunities for learning collaboratively, compared to purely face-to-face modalities (Gútierrez-Braojos and Salmerón-Pérez 2015). This approach increases the possibilities of creating an effective learning environment and eliciting more positive responses from students than purely virtual learning (Westbrook 2006). In addition, it produces higher satisfaction levels for introverted students than face-to-face modalities (Downing and Chim 2004).

Although virtual communities are useful resources for university formation, the use of these resources should be supported by suitable pedagogies. In other words, technologies alone do not ensure pedagogical benefits. Teaching strategies are also essential for turning potential benefits of VL into actual outcomes (Dillenbourg et al. 2002). In particular, Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning (CSCL) is becoming one of the most impacting learning and teaching perspectives in higher education. CSCL is a constructivist theory that defends the social nature of learning (Koschmann 1996; Stahl 2006). Introducing CSCL means jointly tackling the use of VL technologies and collaborative learning. CSCL is not just employed in purely online learning. It is also designed to extend face-to-face collaborative learning to virtual communities through software packages (Stahl et al. 2006). Most virtual environments overlap with face-to-face scenes, and so virtual learning communities are useful to enrich classroom activities (Dillenbourg et al. 2002). Therefore, teachers face the challenge of creating hybrid environments in order to improve collaborative relations and, thus, the quality of students’ learning (Álvarez and Mayo 2009; Basheri et al. 2013; Carter et al. 2017; Echeverría et al. 2017; Mehlenbacher 2010).

Collaborative learning

Collaborative learning is generally understood as a process that fosters different forms of interaction that lead to significant advancement of shared ideas to solve learning problems. Learning to work on a team is one of the most important skills professionals must develop to address the challenges of the twenty-first century (Fischer et al. 2007). However, it is not the only reason collaborative learning is reaching a central role in educational practices. Collaborative learning facilitates learning to collaborate as well as collaborating to learn. Several authors have pointed out the benefits of collaborative conditions for the quality of the learning (Deutsch 2006; Johnson and Johnson 1989). In social interaction situations, learners can exhibit opposing centrations or different levels of development that lead to socio-cognitive conflict. The social and cognitive dimensions are involved because divergent arguments are expressed on a relational level (Doise et al. 1975; Mugny and Doise 1983). Through constructive dialogue, the learners can share and discuss their controversy. The coordination of viewpoints and their integration into a higher level representation than the previous one will produce learning improvements (Lacasa 1993).

However, not all socio-cognitive conflict situations necessarily produce learning improvements. In fact, there are two mechanisms of socio-cognitive conflict regulation that individuals can experience in social interaction situations: epistemic and relational (Doise and Mugny 1984; Mugny et al. 1978, 1978–1979; Mugny et al. 1999). Regulation centered on epistemic conflict assumes that the learner’s attention is focused on the task. In this case, collaboration is directed toward building emerging and consensual knowledge that has more explanatory potential than knowledge built separately (Butera and Mugny 2001; Doise and Mugny 1984; Mugny et al. 1999). Regulation focused on relational conflict deals with the evaluation and affirmation of self-competence. Therefore, whereas the regulation of epistemic conflict leads to improve understanding and knowledge, relational regulation leads to the defense of each actor’s own capacity or competence through the affirmation of his/her own point of view. In a subconscious effort to protect their identity, learners try to be right, even when this means missing valuable learning opportunities. Arguments expressed in the regulation of relational conflict are directed toward assessing one’s own competence, even when this stands in the way of learning. By contrast, in epistemic regulation, the interchange of opinions is directed toward conflict resolution. Thus, the quality of reasoning is improved, and learners who are engaged in the knowledge problem benefit from a broadened viewpoint (Mugny and Doise 1978). Therefore, progress in the learning process will be gained through the coordination and integration of different viewpoints, leading to the creation of a shared conceptualization at a higher level of abstraction.

Making collaborative learning effective

Research suggests that just asking students to collaborate does not guarantee higher quality learning (Neugebauer et al. 2016). Students’ goal structures should be taken into account (Deutsch 1949). Indeed, effective collaborative learning is achieved by stressing positive interdependence (Deutsch 2006; Johnson and Johnson 2004), which increases whenever individuals move their goals closer together. Teaching strategies and tools have an impact on students’ goal structures and, thus, on both attitudes and/or the quality of the learning, as discovered by Baer et al. (2010), Cheng-Huan and Chiung-Hui (2016), Johnson and Johnson (1989), Ke and Grabowski (2007), or Yu (2001), for instance. The notion of positive interdependence appeared for the first time within Social Interdependence Theory (Deutsch 1949). Society makes people set up relationships in such a way that one person’s actions may affect another’s goal achievement (Table 1). Social interdependence theory analyzes the general case: when the actions of all individuals affect everyone else’s outcomes.

As Deutsch’s theory states, goal structures determine interactions between individuals, whereas the interaction patterns determine the outcomes of a certain situation. Here, a goal refers to a desired future of the state of affairs; thus, a goal structure is a specification of the type of interdependence among individuals’ goals. Deutsch (2006) proposed two types of goal interdependence. The first one is positive interdependence, which arises when the probability of one person’s goal attainment is correlated (positively) with the likelihood of another obtaining his goal. The second one is negative interdependence, which arises in the opposite case.

The set of different individuals’ sequential or simultaneous actions that affect the outcomes of other actors engaged in the situation is defined as an interaction (Johnson and Johnson 2005). Three types of interaction are defined in Social Interdependence Theory: (1) Actions that increase the probability of others’ success in achieving their goals are promotive interactions; (2) actions that increase the probability of one’s own success and reduce other individuals’ possibilities of success are oppositional interactions; and (3) when individuals take actions that promote their own success without affecting the goal attainment of others, there are no interactions. Positive interdependence gives rise to promotive interactions, whereas negative interdependence results in oppositional interactions (Johnson and Johnson 2005).

Different situations such as constructive/destructive processes of conflict resolution or cooperative/competitive interaction when solving a problem or learning can be analyzed using Social Interdependence Theory (Deutsch 2006). Within a learning community (like a classroom), cooperative relations appear when the goals of the members are positively interdependent (promotive interactions), whereas competitive relations emerge when there is negative interdependence among goals (oppositional interactions). When no interactions appear in a group, members are working individually in the community. There is one a priori goal structure of positive interdependence in learning situations, due to the fact that all the members share the same goal: to learn. However, in practical situations, the classroom dynamics are full of competitive relations. Personal concerns, disagreements between classmates, or grades are some of the causes that may lead to losing focus. Hence, teaching methods play an essential role in emphasizing positive interdependence, that is, cooperative learning relations. The question then is whether these sorts of relations have positive effects on learning.

Beyond positive interdependence: intergroup competition

When intergroup competition is introduced as a learning condition, individuals are usually supposed to collaborate with their group mates. Combinations of intragroup collaboration and intergroup competition involve a double effect: On the one hand, the groups must make a greater effort to achieve a competitive goal. On the other hand, there is simultaneous collaboration within each group, which makes learning easier (thanks to socio-cognitive conflict) and may lead individuals to counteract negative emotional effects (because they are part of a group). Nevertheless, it is not clear what effects intergroup competition has on learning. This question has concerned researchers in recent years, but their results seem to be inconclusive. A summary can be found in Table 2.

Regarding the regulation of socio-cognitive conflict, studies about competition and collaboration reveal that students who participate in competitive learning environments are more likely to focus on relational conflict. In this way, motivation may decrease, as well as attitudes toward learning and academic outcomes (Butera et al. 2010). Likewise, Mugny and his colleagues found that collaborative conditions promote the regulation of epistemic conflict. Receiving criticism, as long as it does not interfere with the epistemic process, may lead the receiver to integrate and take advantage of it and progress (Doise and Mugny 1984; Quiamzade et al. 2013). As a consequence, epistemic conflict prevails over relational conflict when the interaction is not perceived as a threat. In this case, individuals not only consider their own standpoint, but they are also capable of empathizing and, thus, are more likely to learn. By contrast, in competitive conditions, the climate may be perceived as a dispute. In this case, individuals question the validity of every figure or piece of information, regardless of the source, and so regulation is more centered on relational conflict, specifically on oneself and the interlocutor (Mugny et al. 1984, 1975–1976, 1978–1979).

Regarding the outcomes of learning and other attitudinal dimensions, a wide range of research approaches exist. Tauer and Harackiewicz (2004) found that both collaborative and intergroup competitive conditions have positive aspects, so that proper instruction that includes both can lead to high motivation and quality learning. In turn, Baer et al. (2010) found better levels of creativity for low and high competition and worse levels for intermediate competition. From the CSCL approach, there are studies that show better student engagement, learning achievement, and creativity when groups compete with each other (Cheng-Huan and Chiung-Hui 2016 in higher education and Chen and Hwang 2016 in elementary school). Likewise, some papers reveal better attitudes toward the subject and more positive interpersonal relationships in the intergroup competitive case (Yu 2001). Other investigations indicate that competitive situations promote learning, whereas purely cooperative relations improve positive attitudes (Ke and Grabowski 2007). When hybrid modalities are implemented, Regueras et al. (2009) show that collaborative learning with intergroup competition is more effective than pure collaborative learning. Arnab et al. (2015) also reach similar conclusions, although their results are less significant. Other studies in hybrid environments explore the comparison of different levels of competition. Yu et al. (2008) found that students in anonymous team competition conditions exhibited significantly better levels of motivation and satisfaction than those in the face-to-face condition. In turn, Wang et al. (2017) observed greater engagement in collaborating in an unrewarded competitive regime than in a zero-sum competitive situation. Finally, no previous studies were found that analyze the relationship between learning conditions in a face-to-face environment and the quality of the contributions in virtual learning communities.

Our research question arises at this point. We wonder whether learning conditions in the face-to-face environment influence the quality of learning students show in the virtual community. This paper intends to provide clues that help to understand the effects of different types of interdependence on hybrid learning environments.

Problem, objective, and hypothesis

We propose the following question: In a hybrid environment, what learning condition in the face-to-face environment is the most effective for producing greater participation and learning in the virtual community? Thus, the objective of this study is to analyze the effect of different face-to-face learning conditions (cooperative, intergroup competition, and inter-individual competition; see condition parameter in methodological issues section) on the participation and learning of students in the virtual community.

The hypothesis in this study is that students working in competitive intergroup conditions in the small-group sphere show higher levels of positive interdependence than in other learning conditions. In addition, competitive intergroup conditions in the small-group sphere turn into cognitively deeper contributions in the virtual community sphere. In turn, students in the collaborative condition tend to tackle epistemic conflict more, show greater positive interdependence, and make cognitively deeper contributions than students in the inter-individual competition condition.

Methodological issues

Participants

This study took place at the University of Granada (Spain). The participants in the full investigation were 36 (94.44% females) undergraduates enrolled in the subject of educational research, which was part of a 4-year social education degree program. The students’ participation in the virtual environment was obligatory, making up 40% of the final grade.

Learning environment

Analogous to professional research activity, Gutiérrez-Braojos and Salmerón (2012) suggested that work in the classroom should be structured around three spheres of constructive activity in order to optimize the effectiveness of a learning environment: individual, collaborative in small groups, and communitary. This proposal has been followed in this study, and so students worked in every sphere. In the individual sphere, activity is carried out by a single student in one portfolio per content unit. The portfolio includes personal reflections about the topics and some ideas of other schoolmates that the student perceived as the most impacting. The choice of each of the selected ideas must be justified. Results for this sphere are not included in the following section because they are not related to the researchers’ objective. In the face-to-face sphere, activity is based on small-group collaboration. There were four small groups per content unit in the classroom. Each group had three members in order to facilitate comprehension of the subject. In the virtual community sphere, collaborative activities were designed to reflect on and solve several tasks or knowledge problems per content unit. In each unit of content, there were activities with three levels of complexity: comprehension, application, and reflection. For example, in the second unit about mixed-methods research, students had to identify conceptual mistakes from propositions about main ideas from the unit and identify types of mixed methods from an authentic case (comprehension task). Later, they had to provide an adequate mixed method for a given authentic research problem. Finally, they had to discuss and elaborate a shared reflection about the mixed-method unit. The unit was developed in the Knowledge Forum (KF) virtual platform to facilitate asynchronous communication (Scardamalia 2004). The Knowledge Forum environment includes: (1) a main menu with tools designed to edit collaborative knowledge building. For this purpose, the KF offers an interface that provides interaction scaffolds to facilitate collective knowledge building (e.g., ‘I need to understand,’ ‘a better theory,’ ‘putting our knowledge together’); (2) a configuration menu to set up the basic functions of the virtual environment (type of scaffold to use, display of contributions’ authorship, etc.); (3) tools to browse and create discussion windows (Fig. 1); and (4) a menu to analyze and assess activity within the platform.

Method

A Latin Squares design was applied to carry out the full investigation. It took two parameters into account (Table 3).

The ‘phase’ parameter refers to the time spent working on each unit of content. This study analyzes three content units in the subject of research methods in education. These content units correspond to three phases. All the groups have the same tasks in the same phase. In each of these phases, students work through individual, small-group, and virtual community spheres. The ‘Condition’ parameter refers to conditions of collaboration and assessment of the learners in the small-group (face-to-face) sphere, where students were distributed in four small groups of three members each. There were three goal structures or conditions, and all the small groups worked under the same condition in each phase. Condition A (collaboration): The groups collaborated with each other to resolve the activities proposed. Each student who participated in this condition got a bonus point when every group correctly resolved the unit activities. Condition B (intergroup competition): Groups competed with each other to resolve activities. The first group to correctly resolve the activities got a bonus point. Condition C (inter-individual competition): This was a ‘paradoxical’ condition. Students could only collaborate with students in their group. However, only those students who were the first to correctly solve the activities in the face-to-face sphere got bonus points, regardless of the group membership base. In other words, we proposed that these degrees of collaboration can be understood under a continuum from high interdependence to zero interdependence in a learning environment: high interdependence (collaboration among the whole class group, i.e., without competition); close to medium interdependence (collaborative learning intragroup, and competition intergroup); and close to lack of interdependence (collaborative learning intragroup with competition among all the students).

Information-gathering instruments and application procedure

To achieve the objectives of this study, it is not necessary to analyze and present results on the sphere of individual activity. Thus, useful information was collected from two sources: the small-group (face-to-face) sphere and the virtual community sphere.

Small-group sphere

The students’ perception of positive interdependence was obtained by applying the positive interdependence subscale (Ghaith et al. 2007). This subscale is part of a longer scale, the Classroom Life Measure (Johnson and Johnson 1996). The subscale applied is composed of six Likert-type items rated on a 5-point scale, where a rating of ‘1’ indicates that the item is very untrue and ‘5’ that it is very true, for their group. In the present study, the Cronbach’s alpha values were good in two of the learning conditions (collaborative learning condition: .96; competition intergroup condition: .94), and Cronbach’s alpha value was acceptable in the individual competition condition (.694). The instrument was administered in the presence of the teacher during tutorial classes.

Virtual community sphere

The students’ perceptions of socio-cognitive regulation were gathered by applying the socio-cognitive regulation scale (Darnon et al. 2006). This scale is composed of two subscales (epistemic and relational subscale) with three items each. Likert-type items on these subscales are also based on a 5-point scale, where a rating of ‘1’ indicates that the item is very untrue and ‘5’ that it is very true. The alpha values were good for each epistemic regulation subscale in the three conditions (collaboration learning condition: .93; competition intergroup condition: .87; and individual competition condition: .91). However, in the case of the relational regulation scale, Cronbach’s alpha value was good in the condition of collaborative learning without competition (.93); and acceptable in the individual competition condition (.69); but it was not acceptable in the intergroup competition conditions (.51). The instrument was administered in the presence of the teacher during tutorial classes.

Information about participation and learning was collected through automatized records on the Knowledge Forum platform. In all, 379 contributions were recorded. A contribution refers to a student’s written message in the KF with the purpose of participating in the discourse on a specific topic, and it was considered a unit of analysis in this study. Every contribution was rated using the Structure of Observed Learning Outcome taxonomy (SOLO, Biggs and Collis 1982), which has been widely used to evaluate the learning on virtual platforms, specifically to analyze the correction, structural complexity, and originality of the knowledge reflected in the contributions (e.g., Brown et al. 2006; Hatzipanagos 2006; Holmes 2005; Gútierrez-Braojos and Salmerón-Pérez 2015; Schrire 2006). The SOLO taxonomy has five levels of complexity, meta-categorized into two levels (Fig. 2). On the one hand, the superficial level comprises three type of contributions:(1) Pre-structural contributions refer to incorrect or disconnected contributions to relevant knowledge for the community that are overly simple; (2) unistructural contributions are overly simple; and (3) multi-structural contributions provide a large number of content elements, but in a disorganized way, lacking a coherent conceptual structure (multi-structural level). On the other hand, the deep level includes relevant contributions that coherently integrate important aspects of the task requirements (relational level) and/or contributions that involve generalizations, knowledge transference, and novelty (extended abstract level). Finally, other contributions, such as ‘good contribution, I agree with your idea’ or ‘thanks for your explanation, now I understand it better’ were classified as socio-affective contributions.

Variables and analytical procedure

To fulfill the objectives, the analyses were divided into three main stages. In the first stage, we applied an exploratory descriptive analysis of the level of positive interdependence, socio-cognitive conflict regulation, and activity in the VL environment. In the second stage, we carry out a Multivariate General Linear Model analysis in order to analyze differences in the dependent variables regarding both factors, i.e., phases and conditions of learning. In addition, we applied a Bonferroni post hoc test of the number of contributions in order to compare the pairs of learning conditions. Subsequently, in the third stage, another descriptive analysis is included for the factor that explains the statistically significant differences, including the variation coefficient. Data were analyzed using SPSS (Version 18).

Results

Exploratory descriptive analysis

To fulfill the objectives, the analyses were divided into two main stages. In the first stage, an analysis was performed of the students’ perceptions of positive interdependence and socio-cognitive conflict regulation. The second stage corresponded to the analysis of the number of contributions registered in the virtual sphere; i.e., number of deep cognitive, surface cognitive, and socio-affective contributions.

On the one hand, the descriptive analysis of the students’ perceptions shows that the mean for the variable positive interdependence is 3.65 (SD .86), for socio-cognitive relational regulation, 3.67 (SD .64), and for socio-cognitive epistemic regulation, 3.52 (SD .83). Based on the variation coefficients, .24 for the variables positive interdependence and socio-cognitive epistemic regulation, and .17 for the variable socio-cognitive relational regulation, it can be said that the latter variable is more homogeneous than the others. Similarities in the students’ perceptions of these variables can be observed in Fig. 3 (left).

On the other hand, a basic descriptive analysis of activity in the Knowledge Forum platform shows that students generated 338 contributions. The content analysis of the contributions using the SOLO taxonomy reveals that 57.69% are deep cognitive complexity contributions (relational or abstract-extended contribution), whereas 26.04% are surface cognitive complexity contributions. The rest of the contributions are socio-affective (Fig. 3, right).

In addition, a cluster analysis using the K-mean procedure was performed, revealing three learning patterns (see Table 4). Moreover, a discriminant analysis was performed to measure the degree of success of the classification made by the cluster analysis. The results revealed that 98.1% of the original cases were correctly classified. The first cluster, made up of 27 students, presents medium–high scores on positive interdependence, epistemic regulation, and relational regulation. These students showed a moderate number of contributions: deep, surface, and socio-affective, compared to the rest of the clusters. We call these individuals ‘students moderately engaged with epistemic improvement.’ The second cluster, made up 15 students, presents high scores on positive interdependence and epistemic regulation, but low scores on relational contributions. Moreover, students who belong to this pattern show a high number of contributions: a high number of deep and socio-affective contributions, but a low level of surface contributions. We call these people ‘students highly engaged with epistemic improvement.’ Finally, the third cluster, made up 66 students, shows low scores on positive interdependence and epistemic regulation, but high scores on relational regulation. This pattern presents students who show the lowest number of deep contributions, but a high number of socio-affective contributions, compared to the rest of the patterns; however, they also show the highest level of surface contributions. We call these individuals ‘students poorly engaged with epistemic improvement.’

These results led us to test the hypothesis that the learning group may be responsible for the differences between the patterns found.

Multivariate general linear model

By applying multivariate generalized linear models, we compared the means of our variables, depending on the learning condition and phase factors. A post hoc Bonferroni test was applied to find out which means showed statistically significant differences.

Results do not show significant differences depending on the phase parameter, and so we excluded this factor from further analyses. By contrast, learning conditions seem to be factors that have an influence on the dependent variables. In particular, positive interdependence and the number of surface and deep contributions show significant differences depending on the learning conditions, as do relational and epistemic regulations. However, we did not find these significant differences in the variables number of contributions and number of socio-affective contributions (Table 5).

A pairwise analysis of the learning conditions for each dependent variable (Table 6) shows that perception of positive interdependence is significantly greater in the collaborative learning condition and significantly smaller in the learning condition with individual competence. Regarding the variables number of contributions and contributions of socio-affective type, no significant differences were found between the groups. Nevertheless, we found significant differences between the collaborative condition and both of the competitive conditions on the other variables. In particular, when students work in collaborative learning conditions, they generate a significantly higher number of contributions with high cognitive complexity, and fewer contributions with a low level of complexity, than the other conditions. In addition, students perceive that discussions focus more on improving knowledge (epistemic regulation of conflict) and less on the defense of personal views (relational regulation of conflict). On all of these variables, there are no differences between the learning conditions with competition (collaborative learning condition with intergroup competition, and collaborative learning condition with individual competition).

On the other hand, the mean of contributions with cognitive complexity in the collaborative learning condition is 3.28, exceeding the conditions with competition by almost one point (Table 7). By contrast, the mean for the surface contributions in the collaborative condition is .5, a point below the conditions with competition. Likewise, in the condition of collaboration without competition, the students manifest a preference for the epistemic resolution of socio-cognitive conflict, whereas in the competitive conditions, there is a preference for the relational resolution. The perception of positive interdependence is greater in the collaborative condition, with the lowest perception appearing in the condition of inter-individual competition. In addition, it can be observed from the variation coefficients that when the work condition is collaborative, the students’ perception of positive interdependence is more homogeneous, as occurs with the perception of the epistemic regulation and the number of complex contributions. However, in the case of superficial contributions, the least homogeneous condition occurs when the work is collaborative.

As Fig. 4 shows, the number of complex contributions is greater in all of the conditions, as it is 72.4% when the condition is collaborative, 46.39% for intergroup competition, and 46.87% in the inter-individual competition modality. Superficial contributions only represent 11.7% when the work is collaborative, rising to 40.20% when there is intergroup competition, and 33.3% when there is individual competition.

Discussion and conclusions

This empirical study was designed to understand the influence of goal structures on university students’ learning in a hybrid collaborative learning environment. To achieve this aim, an exploratory analysis was performed that focused on measuring positive interdependence, participation, resolution of socio-cognitive conflict, and complexity of students’ contributions, within a virtual environment. The existence of significant differences between contributions across distinct learning conditions was also analyzed.

The results showed that students presented higher levels of positive interdependence when they worked under collaborative learning conditions in the face-to-face sphere. Regarding participation on the virtual learning platform, although there were no significant differences in the number of contributions and socio-affective contributions, it was observed that students who worked in collaborative learning conditions in the face-to-face sphere provided more cognitively complex contributions and less surface contributions than the other conditions. These results are not consistent with some of the studies mentioned above (Arnab et al. 2015; Baer et al. 2010; Cheng-Huan and Chiung-Hui 2016; Ke and Grabowski 2007; or Regueras et al. 2009). The distribution of the cognitive load in the virtual community is a dimension of special interest in this study. The results showed that the coefficient of variation in cognitively deep contributions within the virtual community is smaller than in the other conditions. This indicates that there is lower relative dispersion of knowledge throughout the community when its members collaborate to learn; i.e., collaborative conditions seem to promote a more homogeneous distribution of knowledge, a situation that suggests the notion of collective cognitive responsibility (Scardamalia 2002). The results also reveal that when students participate in collaborative learning environments without competition in a face-to-face environment, a greater number of participants generate more contributions with cognitive quality and fewer contributions with low cognitive quality in the virtual learning environment. Although our findings do not support previous empirical studies, they do agree with the conclusions of Butera et al. (2010) and Quiamzade et al. (2013), who found that collaborative conditions help to improve learning better than competitive orientations. Likewise, this research allows us to conclude that collaboration without competition was more effective than other conditions where competition and collaboration were balanced.

In addition, and contrary to what we expected, we did not observe significant differences between the types of competition. Thus, intergroup competitive conditions led to more positive interdependence than inter-individual competitive conditions. We did not find significant differences in the rest of the dependent variables. On the contrary, in the comparison of intergroup competition and inter-individual competition, no significant differences were found in the quality of learning. These results contrast with those of Yu et al. (2008), who noticed higher motivation in anonymous rivals, and Wang et al. (2017), whose results suggested greater engagement in the unrewarded competition than in the rewarded one. We could infer that these findings partially support Johnson and Johnson’s (1989) and Deutsch’s (2006) studies. These differences between our discoveries and the previous literature are meaningful. We suggest that these differences could be explained by the conditions of our learning environment. We created three learning conditions that could be explained from the parameter called ‘degree of learning collaboration parameter,’ which differs from Deutch’s explanation of interdependence. Deutch proposes two poles of interdependence: positive and negative. We proposed that these degrees of collaboration can be understood on a continuum from high interdependence to zero interdependence in a learning environment: high interdependence (collaboration among the whole class group, i.e., without competition); close to medium interdependence (collaborative learning intragroup and competition intergroup); and close to lack of interdependence (i.e., a ‘paradoxical’ condition in which students were allowed to collaborate with their learning intragroup and also competed with all the students. Students could only collaborate with their group mates. However, only those students who finished first and correctly solved the activities in the face-to-face sphere got bonus points, regardless of their group membership).

To sum up, designing learning environments in conditions of collaboration without competition in face-to-face environments seems to facilitate better quality of learning to a greater extent. We did not find any benefits of intergroup competition or individual competition over collaborative learning without competition. Thus, teaching methods based on goal structures that stress cooperative relations foster higher quality learning than competitive conditions. Therefore, collaborative learning designs without any competition could be considered more consistent with the goal that underpins the main right to education: Each student is able to achieve what he/she has to achieve, taking advantage of the abilities of each and every agent in the learning community (teacher and students) to do so. This could provide relevant insights about how to increase participation and improve achievement of students in the CSCL approach. However, the size of the sample employed does not allow us to generalize. In this regard, we suggest that this study should be replicated in different contexts, including a broader profile of students (various ages and degrees). The characteristics and size of the sample could explain these differences. In other words, applying competitive learning conditions in the entrepreneurial and economic degree could be a more effective teaching strategy than other conditions without competition. However, creating learning environments with competitive learning conditions could be a bad strategy for students who are enrolled in social and educational careers. Thus, some students may feel stressed or uncomfortable with learning assignments that require competition. It is relevant to point out that our sample is mostly composed of women. Our results coincide with previous studies indicating that women show a collaborative learning profile, whereas men tend to exhibit a more individualist learning style (e.g., Yazici 2005; Inkpen et al. 1995). In addition, our sample was small, and so we wonder if the small number of participants, rather than the characteristics of the sample, could explain these differences. Therefore, other studies would be necessary in order to analyze bias due to gender and the size of the sample. In addition, some future lines of research can be explored to add to the understanding of positive interdependence and collaborative learning. One of them is related to Deutsch’s theory, where goal structures define a ‘one dimensional’ continuum of possibilities whose ends are positive and negative interdependence. When intergroup competition comes into play, this framework seems to break down. It is not clear what level of positive interdependence should be expected a priori in an intergroup competitive (with internal collaboration) goal structure. Our findings do not help to understand whether there is a significant intermediate level between pure collaboration and inter-individual competition. Moreover, as mentioned above, some studies present a different picture where intergroup competitive conditions achieve the highest levels of cognitive competencies (right row in Table 2). Thus, the question is how to fit intergroup competition within Social Interdependence Theory (is it some kind of ‘neutral’ condition? Should the theory open up more dimensions?), or equivalently, how to interpret the notion of positive interdependence in these types of goal structures. These questions must be elucidated in future studies.
